newsitem.title: FRANCE: French right unites, left papers over cracks.
newsitem.headline: French right unites, left papers over cracks.

text.p: France's centre-right coalition on Tuesday staged a show of unity, issuing an artfully vague manifesto while left-wing opposition leaders glossed over stark differences on Europe to sign a joint election pact.

In a platform entitled "A new impulse for France", the ruling coalition pledged to stabilise public spending, pursue tax cuts and promote talks on shorter working hours if, as polls predict, it wins the May 25-June 1 parliamentary election.

The latest opinion poll released on Tuesday suggested the government held only a slim lead over the left in voting intentions and would win a reduced majority of National Assembly seats, confirming a series of surveys over the last week.

Socialist leader Lionel Jospin and Communist leader Robert Hue met and issued a joint declaration pledging a shift to a 35-hour working week without loss of pay, the creation of 700,000 youth jobs and a halt to privatisation.

But they stopped short of a common programme for government and did not even try to reconcile their differences over a single European currency, which the Socialists conditionally accept and the Communists oppose.

Presenting the centre-right manifesto, Prime Minister Alain Juppe vowed to modernise the state, free up private initiative, renovate the social welfare system and "make France the motor of a citizens' Europe".

But hours later, outgoing Gaullist Assembly speaker Philippe Seguin cracked the facade of harmony with a speech denouncing what he called the ultra-liberal logic of the rush to European monetary union.
Distancing himself from fellow Gaullist Juppe's programme, Seguin said the fight against unemployment should be at the heart of the campaign and at the centre of government policy.

He lamented that in response to rising unemployment, "people everywhere are mouthing words that seem meaningless: convergence criteria, flexibility, globalisation, federalism". Such slogans were "alibis for inaction disguised as promises of a radiant future", he said.
Juppe said a re-elected government would present to parliament in its first 40 days a five-year plan for holding the increase in public spending to less than the rate of inflation.
Apart from populist pledges to cut the number of ministries to 15 and limit the number of elected offices politicians may hold, the manifesto was strikingly short of detailed proposals.

It avoided specific commitments on taxes, saying only that the coalition would "accentuate the reduction of social welfare charges on lower salaries in exchange for the creation of jobs...continue the reduction of income tax and launch a reform of the professional (business) tax".
Defending the lack of specifics, Juppe told a news conference: "We are not running a campaign for accountants."
He said France faced a strategic choice between more economic freedom and lower taxes on the one hand, and higher public spending and regulation on the other.
The joint Socialist-Communist declaration said: "The fight against unemployment and for jobs is an absolute priority."
It called for wage increases and said: "Together, we reject the idea that people be asked to make new sacrifices."

The declaration sidestepped the issue of whether Communist ministers would enter a Socialist-led cabinet if the left won. Jospin said he was not opposed in principle but junior partners in government would have to bow to the senior party on policy.
A CSA institute poll suggested the coalition's lead over the left had narrowed in the last week to about 40 seats in the 577-seat Assembly.

It forecast the centre-right would win 296, the Socialists and ecologists 237, the Communists 21 and the extreme-right National Front one of the 555 seats in metropolitan France. Coalition supporters hold most of the 22 seats in overseas departments and territories.
Another poll on Tuesday found widespread indifference among voters, more than one third of whom said that neither the centre-right nor the left would address their concerns.
